kidney.head: kidney-head.png
kidney.title: Who Should Get the Kidney?
kidney.desc: Using Moral Decisions to Improve Kidney Exchange Algorithms

info.project goal: A data collection project to explore how to incoporate moral judgments in automated kidney distributions
info.role: Web Design and Development, Experimental Design, Data Analysis
info.collaborators: Dr. Jana Schaich Borg, Dr. Vincent Conitzer, Kenzie Doyle, Dr. Walter Sinnott-Armstrong, Dr. John Dickerson, and Duncan McElfresh

deductio.head: deductio-head.png
deductio.title: Deductio
deductio.desc: a data-driven web-app for logic education

info.project goal: Utilize machine learning algorithms to make better logic problems and represent logical structures using visualization.

dissertation.head: dissertation-head.png
dissertation.title: Doctoral Dissertation in Philosophy
dissertation.desc: Deliberative Bayesianism: Abduction, Reﬂection, and the Weight of Evidence

info.dissertation summary: Philosophy of statistics played an important role in my dissertation, which is a work of statistically informed philosophy. The thesis of my dissertation was motivated by the thought that Bayesian epistemologists’ assumptions about rationality are wildly out of sync with the actual practices of Bayesian scientists and statisticians. Drawing from C.S. Peirce’s notion of abduction and Bas van Fraassen’s voluntaristic probabilism, I argue for a theory of knowledge that gives aspects of an agent’s deliberation—such as experimental commitments, intention, and predesignation—a role to play in rational inquiries.
info.dissertation committee: Dr. Vincent Conitzer, Dr. Felipe De Brigard, Dr. Carlotta Pavese

dcis.head: dcis-head.png
dcis.title: Decision Aids for DCIS Patient
dcis.desc: A National Institutes of Health Funded Project to Help Patients to Make Decision about Cancer Treatment

info.project goal: To develop an internative web-based decision support tool with emphasis data visualization and risk communication to help the decision making of patients diagnosed with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).
info.role: Web Design and Development, Interaction Design, Content Development, Conceptual Framework
info.collaborators: Dr. Marc Ryser, Dr. Ilona Fridman, Jennifer Grant

lokgic.head: lokgic-head.png
lokgic.title: Lokgic
lokgic.desc: Automated Web App for Duke's Logic Course

info.project goal: A fully automated webapp that allows me to flip my logic course at Duke University, by algoritmically generating and grading student assignments.
info.role: Solo project: Web Design and Development, Interaction Design, Content Development, Conceptual Framework

uncertainty.head: uncertainty-head.png
uncertainty.title: Visualizing Higher Order Uncertainty
uncertainty.desc: Conceptualizing and Visualizing Uncertainty about Uncertainty

info.project goal: To conceptualize, implement, and empirically test ways in which the uncertainty of our probability estimates (the uncertainty of uncertainty) can be communicated in a novel manner.
info.role: Web Design and Development, Interaction Design, Content Development, Conceptual Framework, Experimental Design

moralai.head: moralai-head.png
moralai.title: Moral AI Lab
moralai.desc: Can AI and Human make each other more moral?

info.project goal: An interdiscplinary team of researchers, with backgrounds in computer science, mathematics, neuroscience, philosophy, and psychology, from Duke University that focuses on the social and ethical implications of the development of artificially intelligence system.
info.collaborators: Dr. Jana Schaich Borg, Dr. Vincent Conitzer, Kenzie Doyle, Dr. Walter Sinnott-Armstrong, Dr. John Dickerson, and Duncan McElfresh
